comment.author: 18774104@N00
comment._content: From a Google-cached page listing of "Scientists Who Have Contributed to Our Knowledge of Freshwater Crab Biology," retrieved Jan. 20, 2009 - she is listed under "African Freshwater Crab Carcinologists" Isabella Gordon 18 May 1901 – 11 May 1988 British carcinologist. Obtained her Ph.D. degree (1926) from the University of London, awarded D.Sc. (1928) by the University of Aberdeen, and received the Order of the British Empire in 1961. In her early years she studied echinoderms, and made working visits to the U.S.(Hopkins Marine Station, California; Woods Hole, Massachusetts; U.S. National Museum, Washington D.C.). Assistant Keeper of Crustacea at the British Museum (Natural History) (Now The Natural History Museum, London) until her retiremen in 1966. The original page, apparently compiled by Dr. Neil Cumberlidge at Northern Michigan University, is no longer there. faculty.nmu.edu/ncumberl/Neil/MainFWC-website/FWCCarcinol... There's a piece on her (probably an obit) in the Nov. 1988 issue of the Journal of Crustacean Biology if someone has access to JSTOR. (I don't on my home computer) And in Crustaceana, Vol. 56, No. 1 (1989)

comment.author: 45773689@N03
comment._content:
Isabella Gordon was my grandmother's cousin.I visited her in 1981 at her home in London.
She showed me her publication of the crustacean encyclopaedia with hand painted illustrations of each species.
A woman with great determination to succeed in the men's world of academia in the 1920s.
Chris Griffiths

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content:
Thanks for letting us know about your connection, Chris. We enjoy her picture!

Sincerely,
Effie Kapsalis
